>>Dr. Jeffrey Karp:
What I wanted to do tonight was tell you about

12.text: some of the projects in the lab,

13.text:
but actually go beyond that and tell you a
little bit about the process that we engage in

23.text: We have two types of projects in the lab.

26.text:
One is basic discovery and the other is translation.
I want to focus tonight on translation,

35.text:
but I want to highlight something important
about just doing science in general

39.text:
and that is that it's extremely challenging.
Often, nine times out of ten,

44.text:
when we conduct an experiment, we fail and
so, to then take that science

50.text:
and translate it into products that can help
patients is even more challenging.

58.text:
And I find that when we try to do this, we
tend to approach the problem the same way every time

67.text:
and yet we expect different outcomes and I
think there's many reasons for this.

73.text:
There's many reasons why our brains have
actually been trained to be anti-creative,

79.text:
to kind of anticipate what comes next and
to just do the same thing over and over again.

86.text:
So the question is, how do we break free from
this repetitive process.

92.text:
How do we hijack our brains to bring in fresh
ideas?

97.text:
And I would argue that there are many ways
to do this and tonight, I'm going to share

103.text:
In particular, one of the ways that we try
to intercept this repetitive thought process

110.text: is to turn to nature for inspiration.

113.text:
Every living thing, every plant, every animal,
everything that's living that exists today

119.text:
is here because it has overcome an insurmountable
number of challenges

124.text: and those that haven't have quickly become extinct.

128.text:
So, in many ways, we're actually surrounded
by solutions,

133.text:
which are ideas for solving problems. Evolution
is truly the best problem-solver.

139.text:
Hundreds of millions of years of research
and development happening all around us.

147.text:
Let me share with you an example of a project
that we were pursuing when we encountered

152.text:
what seemed to be an insurmountable barrier
and we turned to nature for inspiration.

158.text:
This is Dr. Pedro del Nido. He's Chief of
Cardiac Surgery at Boston Children's Hospital

164.text:
and he approached me one late summer evening
and he said,

168.text:
"You know, I'm trying to treat kids who
have septal defects."

172.text:
These are holes in between the chambers of
the heart.

175.text:
He said, "Sometimes we try to suture that
tissue, but it's so fragile, it just tears."

181.text:
He said, "There's devices that work in
adults, but the challenge is

184.text:
you can't just downsize those devices because
they're permanent

188.text:
and you'd have to come back over and over
for revision procedures

192.text:
because that child's heart is growing over
time."

195.text:
He said, "Isn't it possible, based on
some of the work you've done before

200.text:
that we could develop a patch, a patch that
you could place inside a beating heart,

205.text:
put up against the hole, immediately seal
it. Cells would migrate over this patch,

212.text:
form tissue. The material would fully degrade
and the patient would be left

216.text:
with their own tissue sealing that hole, which
could then grow over time."

221.text:
So, we were really excited to work with Dr.
del Nido, but we knew that this tissue adhesive

229.text:
that we were going to develop would have to
work in

231.text:
potentially the harshest environment inside
the human body, where you have sheer forces.

238.text:
You know, the heart is beating at least 60
beats per minute.

241.text:
You have blood. There's multiple cells in
there. There's enzymes.

247.text:
And so, what we did is we put together design
criteria for the ideal solution.

255.text:
And I'll tell you, this is probably one
of the hardest things that we do

259.text:
because it's easy to come up with a shopping
list of 20 or 30 things.

263.text:
The challenge is how do you narrow it down
to five or six

266.text:
and then, narrow it down to one or two to
drive a completely differentiated solution

271.text: that no one has ever tried before.

273.text:
So, we came up with the short list. We said,
you know, a lot of materials that people have developed,

280.text:
they actually react with blood. They become
fouled with blood.

283.text:
They just don't work in the presence of
blood. Ours has to work in the presence of blood.

289.text:
It has to be biodegradable. It has to be elastic.
It has to match the material properties of

295.text: the tissue that we're applying it to.

298.text:
It also has to be biocompatible so cells can
migrate onto it and form tissue,

302.text:
that tissue bridge that I spoke of. And then,
when you put it in place, we have to think

309.text:
They're not just going to put it in place
and they're done.

311.text:
They're going to want to position it to
the right location and it can't wash out

317.text:
And then, Dr. del Nido and other clinicians
that we spoke to said,

320.text:
"You know, there's some materials in the
clinic that cure within a minute or 10 minutes,"

326.text:
but they said, "We don't want to be at
the mercy of the technology.

330.text:
We want to be in control of the technology.
We want on-demand adhesion.

334.text:
We want to place this thing and when we're
ready, we want to cure it to its final state."

339.text:
And we had developed a number of materials
that could address a lot of these criteria,

343.text:
even the on-demand because we have light-activate-able
materials.

348.text:
But there were two criteria that we really
had no idea how to get around:

353.text: resistant to blood and resists wash-out.

355.text:
And so, we turned to nature for inspiration.
We said,

361.text:
"What creatures exist in nature within wet,
dynamic environments

367.text:
that may mimic the environment where this
adhesive would have to work?"

371.text:
And so, we turned to sandcastle worms in the
sea and slugs and snails on the land

378.text:
and what we noticed is that these creatures
actually had two things in common.

383.text:
One was viscous secretions and we know that
viscous things like honey, for example,

388.text:
honey on a plate, will stay put. If I put
honey here and try to wash it away,

392.text:
it's actually going to take some time because
of these viscous adhesive interactions.

398.text:
And then, when we looked at these viscous
secretions, we also noticed

401.text:
that they contained hydrophobic agents and
hydrophobic agents can repel water.

406.text:
So, we said aha. What if we developed a precursor
glue that we could put inside a beating heart

413.text:
that was hydrophobic? As soon as it contacted
the tissue, it would repel the blood

419.text:
away from the tissue and because it's viscous,
it would stay in place long enough

423.text: for the clinician to shine light to cure it.

427.text:
So that was great, but how are we going to
make the thing adhesive?

431.text:
When you walk around Boston, as I'm sure
some places here in New York,

435.text:
you see buildings like this, covered in ivy
and I don't know if anybody has gone

441.text:
up to the ivy and tried to pull it off, but
it's remarkable the amount of force that's required

447.text:
and lucky for us, the mechanism through which
ivy attaches so strongly was recently elucidated

455.text:
Ivy has these root hairs, which are almost
like heat-seeking missiles.

459.text:
They go up and down the building and they
look for crevices and when they find a crevice,

464.text:
they insert the root hair in, they shrivel
up and they mechanically interlock.

471.text: And so, that gave us an idea.

473.text:
If we could develop a glue that upon contact
with tissue, if it could infiltrate into the tissue,

479.text:
and then, we cure it with light, we would
have a tissue-like Velcro

485.text:
and it potentially would work on almost any
tissue in the body.

489.text:
So, after about two or three years of multiple
iterations,

494.text: we were able to address all the design criteria.

497.text:
Now we have a glue, but there's another
challenge because often,

501.text:
if you go to CVS, for example, or Walgreen's
to get a Band-Aid, you don't just have

507.text:
cotton gauze with glue. There's actually
a backing layer, which is paper or plastic

511.text:
to provide structural support. We needed a
backing layer.

515.text: This is a very harsh environment in the heart.

518.text:
We had to design a completely new material
and this material had to have

522.text:
an additional design criteria. In addition
to being degradable and elastic,

528.text:
it also had to be transparent because we're
going to shine light through it to activate

532.text:
an adhesive on the opposing side. There are no recipes
in the literature, the academic literature,

540.text:
for how to do this. We just had to do brute
force, but we were able to come up with another

544.text:
material that was completely transparent, as you can
see here, and also, elastic.

548.text:
We could stretch it over and over again and
it wouldn't lose its properties.

553.text:
After performing multiple experiments, we
moved to an extraordinarily challenging experiment,

560.text:
one that would mimic the exact application
of where this patch would go.

566.text:
We had to put this inside a beating heart,
right on the septum where you have these holes.

573.text:
And so, what we did is working with Dr. del
Nido, he had developed this cardio-port device.

578.text:
We put our patch on the very end of the device
and then, we made a small incision in the

584.text:
myocardium, the outside of the heart, in a pig model.
This is a live pig.

589.text:
We pushed this up against the septum. We shined
the light for 20 seconds and here's what happened.

596.text:
What you can see directly after the procedure
is we have the patch in the middle here

601.text:
that has attached. We came back after four
hours and added epinephrine to increase the heart rate.

609.text:
We needed to test this at the full range and
watch what happens.

615.text:
We see here the patch still remains attached
in both of these pigs.

622.text:
We came back after 24 hours and the patch
was still there.

628.text:
And since we've conducted this experiment,
we've also partnered with another laboratory

634.text:
to develop a device so that we can place this
patch through a blood vessel.

639.text:
We don't have to make an incision in the
myocardium,

642.text:
which would be non-ideal, of course, for the
patient.

646.text:
We can actually put a tube into a blood vessel,
fish it into the heart and then,

651.text: deploy it in a more minimally-invasive fashion.

655.text: We continue to advance this in the laboratory,

659.text:
but we've also been able to test this in
multiple other models.

662.text:
We showed we could seal the carotid artery
of a pig. We could seal the aorta of a pig.

667.text:
This attaches to almost every tissue in the
body and because of that,

671.text: we decided this is ready for translation.

673.text:
And so, we started a company called Gecko
Biomedical in late 2013

680.text:
and the company has now been able to manufacture
this glue at large scale.

686.text:
It's shelf-stable and they're expected
to be first in man in March of this year for

703.text:
In addition to bioinspiration, I wanted to
share with you another tool that we've been

710.text:
and it's something that I've realized,
in terms of looking at the full translational spectrum.

714.text:
I've realized that you can't help a patient
unless you keep your solution extraordinarily simple.

723.text:
You have no idea how many technologies have
been developed in laboratories

728.text:
and have been shown to work in animal models,
but have not been translated to patients

733.text:
and often, these fail because they can't
be manufactured. They're just too complicated.

739.text:
And so one of the principles that we have
been trying to employ in the laboratory is one

745.text:
that we call radical simplicity and let me
show you an example of how we've used this.

753.text:
Patients that have ulcerative colitis, almost
all patients, will require enema-based therapy

759.text:
at some point in their treatment regimen.
And enemas have a lot of challenges.

765.text:
One, the patient needs to retain that for
long periods of time to get good drug exposure.

772.text:
The systemic absorption of the drug is also
very high and so, this can go throughout the body,

779.text: causing systemic side effects and patients need to dose every day, which is extremely inconvenient.

786.text:
So, we were interested in asking the question,
could we develop a solution to this

791.text:
that would address all three of these challenges
and for this, to keep things as simple as possible,

799.text:
we turned to the Generally Recognized as Safe
List by FDA.

804.text:
This is a list of agents that's on the FDA
website that basically says, if you use these

808.text:
in certain concentrations and they're topical,
then it's extremely safe.

814.text:
We're going to minimize technology risk
if we can pick agents directly off this list

819.text: and so, what we did is the following.

822.text: We scoured that list for agents that are amphiphiles.

828.text:
These have a hydrophobic group that doesn't
like water and a hydrophilic group that likes water.

835.text:
In addition, we also looked for agents that
had an enzyme-cleavable bond

840.text: between the hydrophobic and hydrophilic moieties.

843.text:
What's amazing is if you take an amphiphile
that has this hydrophobic and hydrophilic properties

849.text:
and you put it into water, it doesn't dissolve,
but with the right solvents

854.text:
and the right temperature, you can get it
to dissolve.

858.text:
As you cool that, what we can do is coax that
system, those molecules, to assemble,

864.text:
to stack one on top of the other. The groups
that don't like water will point inward

870.text:
and the groups that like water will point
outward.

874.text:
And we can coax this system to form a hydrogel
that looks like this.

881.text:
This is an electron-micrograph of that hydrogel
system. It's nanofibrous.

887.text:
This looks just like butter or margarine at
room temperature and has very similar consistency.

893.text:
But what you're looking at here is a single
molecule that is stacked over and over and

898.text:
There's nothing else present except that
molecule.

903.text:
And that molecule was taken from the Generally
Recognized as Safe List.

907.text:
What we can do during that assembly process
is we can entrap drugs, all kinds of different drugs.

913.text:
We've tried many and then, in the presence
of inflammation at sites of ulcers,

918.text:
you have high concentrations of degradative
enzymes and so, what will happen is that

924.text:
if this gel, if this material reaches the
ulcer, it'll be disassembled and the drug

931.text:
So, we've developed an inflammation-responsive
material that's extremely simple.

940.text:
And we went one step beyond that. We knew
at sites of ulcers that typically you have

947.text:
positive charge and to increase the potential
for targeting to minimize systemic absorption,

954.text:
to minimize potential for this gel to disassemble
at a site of healthy tissue,

960.text:
we target it by selecting an amphiphile from
that list that had negative charge.

966.text:
We then broke this gel into small particles and
we did enema infusion into a number of animal models.

973.text:
We were able to show with this system that
we could selectively target the ulcers.

979.text:
These gel-based particles attach specifically
to the diseased tissue,

984.text:
whereas we didn't see any attachment to
the healthy tissue.

989.text:
We also were able to show, because when you
infuse this gel in particle form,

994.text:
it attaches to the ulcer so quickly, the patient
wouldn't have to hold in-

998.text:
they wouldn't have to retain that enema.
And then, it sticks to the ulcers

1002.text:
and it continuously releases in the presence
of those enzymes.

1005.text:
In fact, we saw that it could remain attached
to the ulcers for long periods of time

1010.text:
and because we're not getting release of
the drug at the healthy tissue,

1014.text:
we were able to reduce the systemic exposure
of the drug by five- to ten-fold with our system,

1022.text: meaning less potential systemic side effects.

1025.text:
And then, we moved to a model where we dosed
the enema to the animals every other day

1032.text:
and when you do this with a drug alone, it
doesn't work.

1035.text:
You have to dose every day, but with our gel,
because it attaches to the ulcers and stays there

1041.text:
and continuously releases the drug, we're
able to dose every day

1045.text:
and get a major improvement in the healing
of the tissue.

1052.text:
And now, I'm working with a number of gastroenterologists
to try to bring this forward to the clinic.

1059.text:
Another example of where we've tried to
harness this concept of radical simplicity

1064.text:
can be shown here. This is my hand and one
day, I was wondering

1073.text:
why do I have this burning, itching, red reaction
next to my wedding ring.

1081.text:
Am I allergic to my marriage, maybe? I don't
know. It was bothersome.

1087.text:
This is 24-carat gold and so, I started to
wonder, you know, what was going on.

1092.text:
This wasn't happening on any of the other
fingers and I read that maybe this was a nickel allergy.

1099.text:
And so, what I did is what I think all of
you would do if you had access to a laboratory,

1104.text:
was I brought my ring to the lab and analyzed
for nickel and sure enough,

1111.text:
the substrate turned red, meaning that this
wedding ring, which we got from a family friend,

1117.text:
24-carat gold, contains a good amount of nickel,
which is extremely cheap and is used as a filler.

1126.text:
And then, I realized I'm part of the 9%
of the population that has a nickel allergy,

1132.text:
9% of the world population and it's one
of these things that when you reach a certain

1138.text:
then you become allergic and you're allergic
for life and it's almost impossible to avoid.

1143.text:
It's everywhere. It's in belt buckles.
It's in coins. It's in eyeglass frames.

1150.text:
FitBit had to recall one of their product
lines because it was leaching a lot of nickel.

1154.text:
And so, when we looked to see what was currently
available in the clinic,

1158.text:
there was nothing to prevent these reactions
for people who are allergic

1162.text:
and nothing to prevent someone from becoming
allergic.

1165.text:
Only steroids, which were administered after
the reaction to resolve it.

1170.text:
So, we were determined, I was determined,
to find a solution to this.

1176.text:
And the goal was to kind of do something similar
to some of the sunscreens that exist.

1181.text:
So, some of the sunscreens have nanoparticles
in them that coat the skin

1185.text:
and block the sun from going through. We thought
well, maybe we could create

1190.text:
particles on the skin, but instead of blocking
the sun, they could bind nickel

1195.text:
and prevent that nickel from going into the
skin and then, we could just wash it off.

1200.text:
So, we went back to the Generally Recognized
as Safe List.

1204.text:
We scanned the list and we identified some
agents that we had a hunch could bind nickel

1209.text:
at high affinity when we formulated it as
nanoparticles.

1214.text:
And what we did is we applied this in many
different models in the lab.

1218.text:
This is just one example where what you're
seeing is full-thickness skin,

1221.text:
this is the top of the skin at the top and
the bottom of the skin, the underneath surface,

1227.text:
We put the particles onto the skin and we
added a very high concentration of nickel.

1231.text:
This is calcium carbonate, chalk. The particles
we had put into a cream to apply it,

1236.text:
just like a sunscreen and here you have the
cream alone, the glycerin

1241.text:
and what happens is, is that the nickel binds
to the particles that are on the skin

1246.text:
and doesn't enter the skin, whereas if you
don't have the particles there,

1249.text:
they can directly go into the skin. And then,
if you wash the skin, we can wash off

1255.text:
almost all the particles and all the nickel,
but you can't do the same with the nickel

1261.text:
We tested this in a number of models and we
published a paper

1265.text:
and CNN picked up this paper. They put it
on the home page and they had a little blog

1271.text:
and people started writing in saying, "I'm
desperate. When is this going to be available?"

1276.text:
And so, we launched a company called Skintifique

1286.text:
And by harnessing this concept of radical
simplicity, the company was able to have

1293.text:
a clinical proof of concept within two years
of the publication and a year later,

1298.text: we had a product on the market.

1300.text:
And the company has been able to maintain
this concept of radical simplicity in new products -

1306.text: and let me just quickly show you one example.

1309.text:
So, this is a hydrating gel that the company
developed, where what they did is

1316.text:
they looked for agents on the Generally Recognized
as Safe list that could be formulated

1320.text:
as three-dimensional nanostructures that could
bind a ton of water.

1326.text:
And it keeps this water in close contact with
the skin

1330.text:
and skin has natural repair mechanisms where
if you keep it hydrated

1333.text:
and prevent irritating agents from interacting,
it can actually self-heal in many cases.

1339.text:
This product only has eight ingredients and
we can entrap active agents from the GRAS list

1349.text:
Let me just show you one example of a patient
who approached the company

1354.text:
who had psoriasis. He had tried everything
and he started using this cream multiple times a day

1362.text:
and within weeks, his skin completely cleared
up. And now, he's been using this cream

1368.text:
for about a year-and-a-half and the skin condition
has not come back.

1374.text:
This has been tried now on multiple patients
with eczema, psoriasis and other skin conditions

1380.text: and it's been performing very well.

1382.text:
This company has now been able to launch these
products across the globe.

1388.text:
Now, finally, I just want to tell you about
one more problem that we've been working on

1396.text:
where we've tried to employ this concept
of radical simplicity.

1399.text:
We want the solution to get out there as quickly
as possible.

1404.text:
Some of you may be familiar with the dangers
of button cell, or coin cell, batteries.

1409.text:
Kids under the age of six get a hold of them,
accidentally ingest them.

1414.text:
They get stuck in the esophagus. They short-circuit.
A current forms and then,

1418.text:
it can burn a hole through production of hydroxide
ions, through the esophagus.

1424.text:
So, we were determined to try to solve this
problem and we made a simple observation.

1429.text:
Any time you put a battery in a device, there's
always the spring you need to push against.

1432.text:
You don't just drop it in. You kind of have
to click it in and we did a number of calculations.

1438.text:
We turned to the literature and we realized
that the force that the esophagus exerts on a battery,

1445.text:
a button cell battery, is much less than the
force required

1449.text:
to put the battery into a device against this
spring.

1452.text:
And, so that gave us a design angle. So, we
asked, "Are there any off-the-shelf materials

1459.text:
we could use to solve this problem?" because
we don't want to invent something new.

1462.text: It would just take too long.

1464.text: And that led us to touch screens.

1467.text:
Some of the touch screens that are available
work by a pressure-sensitive action,

1472.text:
where where you touch, you actually get a
current that forms to describe that location.

1479.text:
We purchased these materials. We attached
them to the battery.

1484.text:
We also added a silicon layer over the gasket
that connects the anode to the cathode

1488.text:
to completely waterproof the system and then,
we fed those batteries to pigs.

1491.text:
And we showed that with this coating, if you
don't have the coating,

1493.text:
you get significant damage. This damage occurs
within two hours. It's very fast.

1498.text:
But with the coating, we get absolutely no
damage.

1500.text:
We've put this into stomach acid for 48
hours and nothing happens. There's no reactions.

1507.text:
And so, when this coating is on the battery
outside of a device, it's insulating.

1512.text:
If you accidentally swallow it and it gets
trapped in the esophagus,

1515.text:
the forces can't convert that coating because
it's pressure-sensitive, to a conductor,

1519.text:
so it remains insulating. But when you put
it into a device, the pressure converts

1524.text:
to an effective conductor and it works just
normally.

1528.text:
And now, we're working with some of the
major battery manufacturers,

1531.text:
as well as the U.S. government poison control
and the U.S. Consumer Product and Safety Commission,

1537.text: to bring this technology to the market.

1541.text:
So, in closing, I shared with you a couple
of tools that we've been using in my laboratory

1546.text:
to try to focus on translational projects,
to try to get over those hurdles and really break free

1552.text:
from this repetitive thought process. I spoke
about bioinspiration.

1556.text:
We're not doing bio-mimicry here where you
mimic nature directly.

1560.text:
We're doing bioinspiration, where you take
a basic idea in nature and then,

1565.text: improve on it for one's own purposes.

1567.text:
And then, radical simplicity. How can we keep
what we do as simple as possible

1572.text:
at every single step, to maximize the potential
that what we work on can help patients

1579.text: as soon as possible? Thank you so much.
